cleaned_comment: The Chinese is something that interests me a lot, because I was born in Asia. I was born in Asia, I am also an immigrant. Because when I came to France I was six years old. But the Chinese are one of the most important elements of immigration in the world, and in your country it may be very visible, but in Africa, we could also talk about Chinese immigration because it is an immigration that - I have the impression - we will not be able to control in the coming years. It is one of the two most populated countries in the world and they need to go elsewhere, but there is a very positive element of Chinese immigration that we have seen in France: When I was working in Paris, I was working next to the so-called "China Town" of Paris, the 3rd arrondissement, and I can tell you that in five years people went to restaurants much more than before and the restaurant habits have changed too much, because before the Chinese opened restaurants and well go to restaurants at lunchtime when we went out of work, It cost us twice as much as it does now and all the restaurants have transformed themselves to offer meals that are worth - that's what we call meal tickets that are distributed by the companies, so there's been something very positive in that but it represents, I completely agree, a global risk.
speech: [21:30] Les Chinois c’est quelque chose qui m’intéresse beaucoup, parce que moi je suis né en Asie. Je suis né en Asie, je suis aussi un immigré. Parce que quand je suis venu en France j’avais six ans. Mais les Chinois c’est un – je crois que c’est un des éléments les plus importants de l’immigration dans le monde, alors actuelle, chez vous peut-être que ça représente quelque chose de très visible mais en Afrique, on pourrait parler aussi de l’immigration Chinoise parce que c’est une immigration que – j’ai l’impression – on ne pourra pas contrôler dans les années qui viennent. C’est un de deux pays les plus peuplés au monde et ils ont besoin d’aller ailleurs, mais il y a un élément très positif de l’immigration Chinoise qu’on a pu constater en France: Quand je travaillais à Paris, je travaillais à côte de ce qu’on appelle le «China Town» parisien, le 3ième arrondissement, et je peux vous dire que en cinq ans les gens sont beaucoup plus allés aux restaurants qu’avant et les habitudes des restaurations ont trop trop beaucoup changées, parce qu´avant que les Chinois ouvraient des restaurants et bien aller manger aux restaurants le midi quand on sortait du travail, ça nous coutaient deux fois plus chère que maintenant et tous les restaurants se sont transformés à côté pour offrir des repas qui valaient – c’est qu’on appelle nous des tickets-restaurants qui sont distribués par les entreprises, donc il y a eu quelque chose de très positive la dedans mais ça représente, je suis complètement d’accord, un risque mondial. [24:00]

cleaned_comment: Yes, I have to say that in France there is a lot of money dedicated to general training. And in particular to the training of young people or people who are unemployed. And training is not, I would say, the clique [...], which necessarily allows entry into the world of work. There is still a lot of competition in terms of getting into the workplace. Then there is still a lot of unemployment in France - at least when I talk about what I know. And there are organizations, such as the AL? in France, which is the authority that allows appeals on discrimination. And regularly, there is discrimination in hiring for reasons other than the level of training. So it's still more of a cultural difficulty than a difficulty linked to people's skills.
speech: [22 :15] Oui, je dois dire quand même qu’en France il y a quand même des fonds très importants qui sont consacrés à la formation générale. Et notamment à la formation des jeunes ou des personnes qui sont au chômage. Et la formation c'est pas, je dirais la clique[ ?], qui permet forcément l’entrée dans l’univers du travail. Il y a quand même une concurrence importante au niveau de l’entrée  au travail. Puis il y a quand même un chômage important en France – en tous cas quand je parle de ce que je connais. Et il y a des organismes, telle que l’AL[ ?] dans la France qui est donc l’autorité qui permet donc des recoures sur les discriminations. Et régulièrement, il y a de la discrimination à l’embauche pour des raisons autres que le niveau de formation. Donc ça reste quand même une difficulté je dirais plus culturelle qu’une difficulté liée proprement aux compétences des personnes. [23 :25]

cleaned_comment: Is there any possibility or obligation on the part of the EU, which certainly spends considerable funds on development aid, to provide these countries with proof of use? That's the first thing. And the second is: Why can't the EU attach certain conditions to development aid? In the direction of immigration. You could, for example, if people come here and you can send them back again, and that is solved intergovernmentally, then the whole thing would look somewhat different.
speech: [47:27] Gibt es von der EU, die sicherlich beträchtliche Mittel für Entwicklungshilfe aufwendet, irgendeine Möglichkeit oder eine Verpflichtung, diesen Staaten den Verwendungsnachweis zu erbringen? Das ist einmal das erste. Und das zweite ist: Warum kann die EU nicht gewisse Bedingungen an eine Entwicklungshilfe binden? Eben in Richtung einer Immigration hin. Man könnte damit auch schon, zum Beispiel wenn Leute herkommen und die kannst du wieder zurückschicken, und das ist zwischenstaatlich gelöst, dann würde das Ganze schon wieder etwas anders ausschauen. [48:06]

cleaned_comment: The effect of being illegal, there is an answer behind it. When you do something illegal, what do you get out of it? You're welcome. It seems so obvious to me that it's illegal. I couldn't imagine entering a country where there are well established rules. So it's basic. If you establish laws and you don't respect them, then who are you? Even the one who is illegal, he says: there we can do what we want. That's all.
speech: [19:00] L’effet d’être illégaux, il y a réponse derrière. Quand vous faites quelque chose d’illégal, qu’est-ce que vous en obtenez ? De rien. Ça  me parait tellement évident que c’est illégal. Moi je n’imaginais pas d’entrer dans un pays où il y a des règles bien établis. Donc c’est élémentaire. Si vous établissez des lois et vous ne les respectez pas, alors qui êtes-vous ? Même celui qui est illégal, il dit : là-bas on peut faire ce qu’on veut. C’est tout. [19:51]

cleaned_comment: First of all I would like to say that I am very tired. So today I'm going to rest well, so that tomorrow I'll be in order to participate in this discussion. Because today I have hardly slept. That is to say, I found my round to start with this policy, with this discussion this immigration policy. And that the first two opinions are in favor of this policy being defined by the states and not by the European Union. So I totally disagree. I think that the migration policy should be defined in the base by the European bodies. I don't mean to surprise you by saying that each state obviously with its specificity can't adapt its regulations to its own reality. But it is the European Union that must define the rules. Because otherwise we will be regulating because we know that Europe does not speak with one voice. There is the voice of 4, 5 strongest and then this small voice of smaller countries. We have several voices, if we do not overcome this phase, we will never reach anything. Just to give you my opinion. I am not in favor of a federal state, the United States of Europe. I am not in favor of the United States of Europe, no. But if, a certain policy should be defined by the European Union in a global sense. And the immigration policy is one of those policies. Because we have borders inside and also outside. And through the external borders we have to protect ourselves. But from the moment that a person enters the European Union, the person can enter all the spaces of the EU and therefore, the states, or at least those that are part of the Schengen area, almost all the states of the EU must define and have common positions about the immigration policy. I don't think that the future is based on every man for himself, because we already have our internal borders open anyway, because once a person enters an EU state, he is already in the EU. [1 :
speech: [1 :22 :04] Tout d’abord j’aimerais dire que je suis très fatigué. Donc aujourd’hui je vais bien me reposer, pour que demain je sois en ordre pour participer dans cette discussion. Parce qu’aujourd’hui je n’ai presque pas dormi. C'est-à-dire, j’ai trouvé ma ronde de commencer par cette politique, par discussion cette politique d’immigration. Et que les deux premiers avis, premiers opinions soient favorable à ce que cette politique soit défini par les états et non par l’Union Européenne. Alors je suis tout à fait en désaccord. Je pense que la politique de migration doit être définie dans la base par les organes Européens. Je ne dis[ ?] surprendre de vous dire que chaque état évidemment avec sa spécificité ne puisse pas adapter ses régler à sa propre réalité. Mais c’est l’Union Européenne qui doit définir les règles. Parce qu’autrement nous serons en train de réguler parce que nous savons que l’Europe ne parle pas à une seule voix. Il y a la voix de 4, 5 plus forts et puis de cette petite voix de plus petites pays. On a plusieurs voix, si on ne dépasse pas cette phase, on ne donc arrivera jamais à rien. Simplement pour vous placer mon opinion. Je ne suis pas en faveur d’un état fédéral, les Etats-Unis de l’Europe. Je ne suis pas en faveur des États-Unis de l’Europe, non. Mais si, une certaine politique doive être définie par l’Union Européenne en sens de globalité. Et la politique d’immigration est une de ces politiques. Parce que nous avons des frontières à l’intérieur et aussi à l’extérieur. Et par les frontières extérieures nous devrons nous protéger. Mais à partir du moment, que la personne entre dans l’Union Européenne, la personne peut entrer dans tous les espaces de l’UE et donc, les états, ou du moins ceux qui font partis de l’espace Schengen, presque tous les états de l’UE doivent définir et avoir des positions communes à propos de la politique d’immigration. Je ne pense pas que l’avenir se base sur chacun pour soi, parce que nous avons de toute façon nos frontières internes déjà ouvertes, parce qu’une fois la personne entre dans un état de l’UE, elle est déjà dans l’UE. [1 :24 :55]

cleaned_comment: We had already said earlier that because of the aging of the population, it is very important that we provide for the next generation, so to speak, which we ourselves are no longer able to offer, so such a new generation must also be led, developed, educated; so it is actually very important right now in this period that we start so that our pensions are also secured in the future.

[56:53]

cleaned_comment: The EU - we are here in Brussels to talk about the EU and the individual states - the EU should, in my view, take more care that the external borders are closed; that it is checked that no illegal immigrants seep into the individual states and - well - maybe also take away the work of the locals. So, the EU is challenged and then, of course, the individual states within the EU.

Also, die EU ist gefordert und dann natürlich die einzelnen Staaten innerhalb der EU. [23:11]

cleaned_comment: I have to agree with Manfred on that. How then - this would be a question for the experts - do the experts want to convey to the incoming skilled workers, however skilled, the incentive to stay with us, when we demonstrably have so and so many skilled workers leaving every year. I cannot explain to myself what incentives are to be created so that the skilled workers really do come to us. Personally, I would be very interested in that. And then, of course, we need immigration - with families - without limits.

Da stellt sich für mich eine ganz spezielle Frage, wenn wir jetzt unser deutsches System jetzt da angesprochen haben; es ist ja richtig, dass wir viel zu viel – eh viel zu wenige Fachkräfte haben. Wie wollen den dann – das wäre eine Frage an die Experten – die Experten den einreisenden wie auch immer Fachkräfte vermitteln, den Anreiz bei uns zu bleiben, wenn wir doch nachweislich momentan jedes Jahr so und so viele Fachkräfteabwanderung haben. Und dann brauchen wir natürlich die Immigration – mit Familien – ohne Begrenzung. [04:47]

cleaned_comment: I would like to add something. The standard of living in Germany is higher than in Poland, so it is understandable that the cost of living is expensive. I may give an example from my area and a few specific examples, but may I calmly maybe also give my example: So I, what I earn and then all additional expenses, so I get gross 2000 zloty, which corresponds to 500 euros, so a quarter approximately, and if I then deducted the insurance premiums and other indispensable expenses, I am left with just half, 1000 zloty and a square meter of living space costs six zloty, so that is, I do not know now how you can convert that. I'm just trying to put it into a logical context with what I find out when I move, because a Polish family has to spend about 90 zloty on electricity alone. So you can do the math yourself that the cost of living is disproportionate. So I don't agree that living in Germany is more expensive than living in Poland, I can't understand that.
speech: [24:55] Ich möchte noch etwas ergänzen. Der Lebensstandard in Deutschland ist ja höher, liegt höher als in Polen, deswegen ist es auch nur verständlich, dass die Lebenshaltungskosten teuer sind. Ich darf ein Beispiel aus meiner Gegend anführen und ein paar konkrete Beispiele, aber darf ich ruhig vielleicht auch mein Beispiel anführen: Also ich, was ich verdiene und dann alle Nebenkosten, also ich bekomme brutto 2000 Zloty, das entspricht 500 Euro, also ein Viertel ungefähr, und wenn ich also dann die Versicherungsbeiträge und andere unverzichtbare Ausgaben abgezogen habe, bleiben mir gerade mal die Hälfte, 1000 Zloty und ein Quadratmeter Wohnfläche kostet also sechs Zloty, das heisst also, ich weiss jetzt nicht, wie man das umrechnen kann. Ich versuche nur, das in logischen Zusammenhang zu bringen mit dem, was ich feststelle bei Abwandern, denn eine polnische Familie muss in etwa 90 Zloty allein für den Strom ausgeben. Sie können sich also selbst ausrechnen, dass die Lebenshaltungskosten unverhältnismässig liegen. Also ich bin nicht der Meinung, dass das Leben in Deutschland teurer sei als in Polen, das kann ich nicht nachvollziehen. [26:47]

cleaned_comment: I am sorry, I was just wondering. In my opinion there is a chance for legalization of the illegal immigrants and perhaps this is the best solution, as we are talking about people who are already here and something must be done. So we can check, whether they have a job, family, whether they are employed and have any prospects. If they are able to take care of their standard of living, apartment, should we put them in jail or arrest them? I do not know. I know that for a longer period of time, politicians have been debating on it. It is hard for me to talk about it and propose a solution, it is hard.

cleaned_comment: Is that directly related to the fact that they are immigrants, or is it just that there are different factors that have arisen, for example that Spain has developed in a special way, or that there are perhaps other moral parameters, other meters, and that there is a new situation overall that did not exist before in Spain. So the population has increased and of course, as the population has increased, of course the prison population is increasing.
speech: [21:26] Hat das jetzt direkt damit zu tun, dass die Einwanderer sind, oder kommt das jetzt einfach nur, dass da unterschiedliche Faktoren sich ergeben haben, zum Beispiel dass sich Spanien da besonders entwickelt hat, oder dass es vielleicht andere moralische Parameter gibt, also andere Meter und dass es eine neue Situation insgesamt gibt, die es vorher in Spanien nicht gegeben hat. Also die Bevölkerung ist gewachsen und natürlich, da sich die Bevölkerung gesteigert hat, steigt natürlich auch die Zahl der Gefängnisinsassen. [22:02]

cleaned_comment: First of all, I have no idea how much money Poland spends on illegal immigrants and I do not know how it would work out for Polish people. So I have no opinion on this issue.

cleaned_comment: I think you have to take measures as much as possible, but that's like having an alarm for example, if you have a dog or an alarm to protect you from the burglars, that can work, but that doesn't protect them 100% from the burglars. It's like with the immigrants, you have to take a lot of measures, take all measures. The repatriation and everything possible to keep this problem as minimal as possible. Thank you.
speech: [50:48] Ich glaube, man muss so viel wie möglich Massnahmen ergreifen, aber das ist so wie mit einem Alarm zum Beispiel, wenn Sie einen Hund haben oder einen Alarm um Sie zu schützen vor den Einbrechern, das kann funktionieren, aber das schützt sie nicht zu 100% vor den Einbrechern. Das ist so wie mit den Einwanderern, man muss sehr viele Massnahmen ergreifen, alle Massnahmen ergreifen. Die Rückführung und alles, was möglich ist, um dieses Problem so minimal wie möglich zu halten. Ich danke Ihnen. [51:31]

cleaned_comment: If we legalize the work of an immigrant, he would be treated equally as an employee of a certain country. This would cause fair and equal competition. If he was a bad employee, he would get fired. It seems to me that here, it is only a question of whether it is legalized by the end of his life if he is in our country, works or is it just the legalization of labour for a given period and let them migrate elsewhere. I really do not know but I think that here this system should base on the equal employee competition. Then it would work really well.

cleaned_comment: I would like to add another aspect, which is that we talk about Europe, we want to be European, we are 27 countries and therefore we must first agree among ourselves. We must first create a basis between us so that these laws are created at the European level. And then we would have more strength. For example, identity card: in our country everyone has an identity card, in the United Kingdom it doesn't even exist. So we don't know how many people there are, how many illegals. We don't even know anymore, how many legal, illegal there are in a certain country and so at that point we don't know how to intervene, so we have to agree, we have to be convinced of the same policy.
speech: [39:19] Je voudrais ajouter un autre aspect, c'est-à-dire qu’on parle de l’Europe, on veut être Européens, nous sommes 27 pays et donc il faut tout d’abord se mettre d’accord entre nous. Il faut d’abord nous créer une base entre nous pour que ces lois soient créées au niveau Européen. Et donc à ce moment-là on aurait plus de force. Par exemple, carte d’identité : chez nous tout le monde à une carte d’identité, au Royaume Unis ça n’existe même pas. Donc voilà, on ne sait pas combien de gens il y a, combien d’illégaux. On ne sait même plus, combien des légaux, illégaux il y a dans un certain pays et donc à ce moment-là on ne sait pas intervenir, donc il faut se mettre d’accord, il faut être convaincu de la même politique. [40:05]

cleaned_comment: In Germany, at least, we have offices where people have to register as soon as they arrive somewhere and there is also a certain system of control, for example if you live somewhere, people can say yes, there are people who live very close to us, are they really registered and so on but the problem of course is when these people stay among themselves, if there are ghettos, then there is nobody who gets in there and so it is impossible. It's true that those who don't officially exist can't be counted.
speech: [24:04] En Allemagne, en tout cas, nous avons des offices où les gens doivent, dès qu’ils arrivent quelque part, s’inscrire et il y a également un certain système de contrôle, par exemple si vous habitez quelque part, les gens peuvent dire oui, il y a des gens qui habitent tout près chez nous, est-ce qu’ils sont vraiment inscrit et cetera mais le problème évidemment c’est quand ces gens restent entre eux, s’il y a des ghettos, à ce moment-là il n’y a personne qui rentre là-dedans et donc c’est impossible. Il est vrai que ceux qui n’existent pas officiellement ne peuvent pas être comptés. [25:44]

cleaned_comment: It's not because they're physically different but because they occupy a lot of territory and they take a lot of share in our economy - that Hungarians could actually make and fill. And in fact we can't compete with their low prices here. They come in and they invade - of course if I'm a mother and I don't have enough money I'll buy Chinese things but that said, they destroy our economy, so there you go, it's something where you have to see both sides of the coin. I don't mind that they are Chinese; what bothers me is that in a country we have arrived at a situation where most of the population is going to buy the cheap Chinese products.
speech: [20:28] Ce n’est pas parce qu’ils sont différents physiquement mais parce qu’ils occupent beaucoup de territoire et ils prennent beaucoup de parts dans notre économie – que les Hongrois pourraient en faite faire et remplir. Et en fait nous on ne peut pas concurrencer leurs prix ici bas. Ils arrivent ils envahissent – bien-sûr si je suis une mère et je n’ai pas assez d’argent je vais acheter des choses Chinoises mais ceci dit, ils détruisent notre économie, donc voilà, c’est quelque chose ou il faut voir les deux faces de la médaille. Moi, ça ne me dérange pas qu’ils soient Chinois; ce qui me dérange c’est que dans un pays on est arrivé à une situation, ou la plupart de la population et qu’en train d’aller acheter les bon-marchés, les produits bon-marchés Chinoises, voilà. [21:19]

cleaned_comment: Yes. I also have another opinion on that. I agree with the gentleman [HA] opposite. I think that the EU rules have to be unified, but there have to be some nuances and some reservations depending. Each country has its own needs again according to the traditions of its own country and also according to the requirements on the part of the officials and other officials. By the way, in the questionnaire that we filled out, there was also an opportunity to give a value, 3 4 5 6. It is difficult, sometimes not so easy to give a correct rating. Concerning the immigration problem, if we include it in a social analysis, we might be enthusiastic, but we also have to consider the economic side. There is not only the social aspect, but also the economic aspect. And these two things are not always classified equally, but both should be taken into account. And then the answer could be different, 4, 5, 6, depending on which criterion you choose as a basis or reference for the evaluation.
speech: [26:10] Ja. Ich habe auch noch eine Meinung dazu. Ich bin einverstanden mit dem Herrn[HA] gegenüber. Ich glaube, dass die Vorschriften der EU vereinheitlicht werden müssen, aber es muss doch gewisse Nuancen und gewisse Vorbehalte geben je nachdem. Jedes Land hat eigene Bedürfnisse noch mal gemäss den Traditionen des eigenen Landes und auch gemäss den Anforderungen Seitens der Beamten und anderen Offiziellen. Im Übrigen gab es hier in dem Fragebogen den wir ausgefüllt haben, auch die Gelegenheit, einen Wert festzuhalten, 3 4 5 6. Das richtig einzustufen von der Bewertung her ist schwierig, manchmal nicht so leicht zu sagen. Ein Einwanderungsproblem betreffend, wenn wir das mal in eine soziale Analyse einfliessen lassen sind wir vielleicht enthusiastisch aber wir müssen das auch berücksichtigen eben von der wirtschaftlichen Seite her eben. Es gibt nicht nur den sozialen Aspekt dabei, sondern auch den wirtschaftlichen. Und diese beiden Dinge werden nicht immer gleichwertig eingestuft, sollten aber beide doch Berücksichtigung finden. Und das könnte dann die Antwort unterschiedlich ausfallen lassen, 4, 5, 6, je nachdem, welches Kriterium man da als Grundlage oder als Referenz wählt für die Bewertung. [27:41]

cleaned_comment: It seems to me that the equalization of the economic levels in Europe, in the EU, has just happened and it seems to me that it would be a greater problem to equalize the level of the economies outside the EU. That is why I would like to ask you: what can we do to equalize the levels of those economies? Needless to say, we could provide them with some amount of money, in terms of jump start their economies, because it is obvious that the faster economy is progressing, the higher the employment is and then, maybe, the willingness to stay in one’s country would be greater. So my question is: how could we aid the other countries? Thank you.
speech: [03:40] It seems to me that the equalization of the economic levels in Europe, in the EU, has just happened and it seems to me that it would be a greater problem to equalize the level of the economies outside the EU. That is why I would like to ask you: what can we do to equalize the levels of those economies? Needless to say, we could provide them with some amount of money, in terms of jump start their economies, because it is obvious that the faster economy is progressing, the higher the employment is and then, maybe, the willingness to stay in one’s country would be greater. So my question is: how could we aid the other countries? Thank you.[04:25]

cleaned_comment: Yes, my name is Björn. If we talk about immigration in my opinion, we have to consider the aspect of right and asylum, because in my opinion many of the people who come to [us] come because they have needs and therefore they also have the right to seek asylum with us and therefore in the letter that we received, I noticed that it is mainly the economic aspects that are underlined and I wonder if the European Union, at the top of a pyramid, still looks at the human aspects and gives priority to the human aspects or if it is rather the purely economic aspects that are taken into account in the first place.
speech: [14:08] Oui je m’appelle Björn. Si on parle d’immigration à mon avis, il faut considérer l’aspect du droit et de l’asile, parce que à mon avis beaucoup des gens qui viennent chez [nous] viennent parce que ils ont des besoins et donc ils ont aussi le droit de chercher asile chez nous et donc dans la lettre que nous avons reçu, j’ai remarqué que ce sont quand-même surtout les aspects économiques qui sont soulignés et donc je me demande, si l’Union Européenne donc au sommet d’une pyramide regarde encore les aspects humains et donne priorité aux aspects humains ou bien si ce sont plutôt les aspects purement économiques qui sont pris en compte au premier lieu. [14:54]

cleaned_comment: Yes I am the same opinion as the Torsten, so if then I find the EU should establish uniform rules. For all countries. So I think it can also not only be that they somehow give people work permits. So that people with better education or so can immigrate rather than those who just ... Yes, I mean they are looking for skilled workers and then they tell other people who should not immigrate. I think that's unfair. So what is actually legal and illegal? So now only from the EU countries. The rules are not quite clear to me. So which people are really allowed to come in? When do they get a work permit and which ones don't? I just don't know them all.
speech: [06:40] Ja ich bin derselben Meinung wie der Torsten, also wenn dann find ich sollte die EU einheitliche Regeln aufstellen. Für alle Länder. Also ich finde, es kann auch nicht nur sein, dass sie den Leuten irgendwie Arbeitserlaubnis erteilen. Also dass auch Leute mit besserer Bildung oder so eher einwandern können als welche die halt… Ja, ich meine die suchen Facharbeiter und dann sagen sie anderen Leuten die sollen nicht einwandern. Ich finde das ungerecht. Also was ist denn eigentlich legal und illegal? Also jetzt nur von den EU-Ländern. Also mir sind die Regeln da auch nicht ganz klar. Also welche Leute dürfen denn wirklich reinkommen? Wann kriegen die eine Arbeitserlaubnis und welche nicht? Also ich kenn die einfach nicht alle. [07:29]

cleaned_comment: I have a question for Udo. The ethnic Germans from the former CIS countries, do they know the German language, or is the problem again lack of language, ignorance - actually it's one of those things; you can't communicate, lack of understanding makes you afraid and fear brings violence, in quotation marks. That is actually for me such a spiral, which arises somewhere again and again. Would it be possible for the EU to say - to come back to the EU level - this topic; a threshold is always to learn the national language in order to have understanding and to get along with each other.
speech: [53:37] Ich habe mal eine Frage an Udo. Die Deutschstämmigen aus den ehemaligen GUS-Ländern, beherrschen die die deutsche Sprache, oder ist mal wieder das Problem mangelnde Sprache, Unkenntnis – eigentlich ist es ja so eine Sache; man kann sich nicht verständigen, Unverständnis mach Angst und Angst bringt in Anführungsstrichen Gewalt. Das ist eigentlich so für mich so eine Spirale, die sich irgendwo immer wieder ergibt. Wäre es das die Möglichkeit, dass man vielleicht auch mal von der EU sagt – um mal auf EU-Ebene wieder zu kommen – diese Thema; eine Schwelle ist immer, die Landessprache zu lernen um Verständigung zu haben um ein Miteinander zu bekommen. [54:17]

cleaned_comment: As far as immigration is concerned, I think we should look at this problem in a more general perspective. Immigration has existed at the European and global level for a long time and it will continue to exist for a long time. We should think of solutions and ideas to use this immigration, this flow that comes and goes in our interest. It is true that immigration, and I believe that immigration should be selective. And this selection would be at the level of education and expertise or abilities in one field or another. It is true that everyone can choose to come to a European state, so that they can live better, to gain autonomy. It might be a low step towards these ideas to try to solve the immigration problem to our advantage. So select in such a way that these people, these immigrants, can function, can help the European community in a development and not create a problem for the EU. For now, I still have some ideas and maybe I will come back with more comments. For now it's this. [1:
speech: [1 :26 :58] En ce qui concerne l’immigration, je crois qu’on devrait regarder ce problème dans une perspective un peu plus générale. L’immigration existe au niveau européen et mondial depuis longtemps et ça existera toujours encore longtemps. On devrait en penser à des solutions et des idées pour utiliser cette immigration, ce flux qui vient et qui part dans notre intérêt.  C’est vrai que l’immigration, et je crois que l’immigration devrait être sélective. Et cette sélection serait au niveau de l’éducation et de l’expertise ou des capacités dans un domaine ou un autre. C’est vrai que chacun peut choisir de venir dans un état européen, pour qu’il puisse vivre mieux, pour gagner une autonomie. Ça serait peut-être un bas pasvers ces idées d’essayer de résoudre le problème de l’immigration à notre avantage. Donc sélectionner de telle manière que ces gens, ces immigrés, puissent fonctionner, puissent aider la communauté européenne dans un développement et non pas créer un problème pour la UE. Pour l’instant, j’ai encore des idées et je vais peut-être revenir avec d’autres commentaires. Pour l’instant c’est ça. [1:28 :46]

cleaned_comment: So it is just how it was with the gypsies in Slovenia. Exactly the same problem appears. In fact, gypsies in Slovenia are problematic because they do not want to work. They do not pay for school, for meals in school, they also do not want to pay. So we need to give them some kind of lesson, teach them something, educate. Sometimes even children do not want to go to school. Give them a rod that would actually fit me. It works somehow. Of course it is not easy. We should first think of why we are doing this, how much we can gain of this?
